elements.content: A novel three-dimensional water network containing both coordinated and lattice water molecules was obtained in the compound [Co2(BPTC)(H2O)6] n ·11nH2O (1). The water network was formed by the hierarchic assembly of bilayer water nanotubes of octamers with crisscross pentamers and helical water chains. A startling feature is the large (H2O)36 water crowns in the water layer in the [001] plane. Leaving the water molecules from the coordination spheres out of consideration, the water network is a two-dimensional water layer formed by T5(2)5(3) water tapes.
elements.clean_text: A novel three-dimensional water network containing both coordinated and lattice water molecules was obtained in the compound [Co2(BPTC)(H2O)6] n ⋅11nH2O (1). The water network was formed by the hierarchic assembly of bilayer water nanotubes of octamers with crisscross pentamers and helical water chains. A startling feature is the large (H2O)36 water crowns in the water layer in the [001] plane. Leaving the water molecules from the coordination spheres out of consideration, the water network is a two-dimensional water layer formed by T5(2)5(3) water tapes.

The water network was formed by the hierarchic assembly of bilayer water nanotubes of octamers with crisscross pentamers and helical water chains. elements.content: Water, because of its fundamental importance for human life and in biological and chemical processes, has been the subject of considerable experimental and theoretical investigations. A variety of discrete water clusters including hexamers, octamers, and decamers1a have been identified and significant progress has been made with respect to characterization of one-dimensional (1D) water chains and tapes. Very recently, some two-dimensional (2D) water/ice layers containing large water rings have also been obtained. Without doubt, the above studies have significantly advanced our knowledge toward understanding the behavior of bulk water. However, water is still not a fully understood substance and how the clusters link to form a large network, which is the bridge between clusters and bulk water, is still a challenging scientific endeavor, so that there are very few examples of three-dimensional (3D) water polymers. An improved understanding of the three-dimensional water network provides novel structural aspects of water and has important implication in the area of structural biology. Herein, we present an infinite three-dimensional water network formed by hierarchically assembling bilayer water nanotubes.
elements.clean_text: Water, because of its fundamental importance for human life and in biological and chemical processes, has been the subject of considerable experimental and theoretical investigations. A variety of discrete water clusters including hexamers, octamers, and decamers1a have been identified and significant progress has been made with respect to characterization of one-dimensional (1D) water chains and tapes. Very recently, some two-dimensional (2D) water/ice layers containing large water rings have also been obtained. Without doubt, the above studies have significantly advanced our knowledge toward understanding the behavior of bulk water. However, water is still not a fully understood substance and how the clusters link to form a large network, which is the bridge between clusters and bulk water, is still a challenging scientific endeavor, so that there are very few examples of three-dimensional (3D) water polymers. An improved understanding of the three-dimensional water network provides novel structural aspects of water and has important implication in the area of structural biology. Herein, we present an infinite three-dimensional water network formed by hierarchically assembling bilayer water nanotubes.

elements.content: Hydrothermal reaction of cobalt powder and H4BPTC (1,1‘-biphenyl-2,2‘,6,6‘-tetracarboxylic acid) in a molar ratio of 1:2 at 160 °C yielded red crystals of 1 [Co2(BPTC)(H2O)6] n ·11nH2O. H4BPTC was synthesized according to the methods previously reported.
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal reaction of cobalt powder and H4BPTC (1,1‘-biphenyl-2,2‘,6,6‘-tetracarboxylic acid) in a molar ratio of 1:2 at 160 °C yielded red crystals of 1 [Co2(BPTC)(H2O)6] n ⋅11nH2O. H4BPTC was synthesized according to the methods previously reported.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis of 1 reveals a two-dimensional coordination framework. There are two half-CoII ions, a half-BPTC ligand, two and two half-coordinated water molecules, and five and a half lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit. Co1 adopts octahedral coordination geometry in which two water molecules (O5 and O6) stand at the apical positions and four carboxylate oxygen atoms comprise the equatorial plane, whereas Co2 is octahedrally coordinated by four water molecules (two O7 and two O8) comprising the equatorial plane and two carboxylate oxygen atoms occupying the apical positions (see the Supporting Information, Figure S2). Octahedral cobalt ions are bridged by carboxyl from BPTC ligands to form chains that are further extended into a two-dimensional framework by BPTC ligands (see the Supporting Information, Figure S3).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray analysis of 1 reveals a two-dimensional coordination framework. There are two half-CoII ions, a half-BPTC ligand, two and two half-coordinated water molecules, and five and a half lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit. Co1 adopts octahedral coordination geometry in which two water molecules (O5 and O6) stand at the apical positions and four carboxylate oxygen atoms comprise the equatorial plane, whereas Co2 is octahedrally coordinated by four water molecules (two O7 and two O8) comprising the equatorial plane and two carboxylate oxygen atoms occupying the apical positions (see the Supporting Information, Figure S2). Octahedral cobalt ions are bridged by carboxyl from BPTC ligands to form chains that are further extended into a two-dimensional framework by BPTC ligands (see the Supporting Information, Figure S3).

elements.content: The most startling feature for 1 is the hydrogen-bonding three-dimensional water network. Herein, we describe it stepwisely. A cage-shaped octameric water cluster was formed by a dimmer of two O10 water molecules and a dimer of two centrosymmetric O11 water molecules associated with O7, O9, O12, and O14 water molecules (Figure a). The octamer has four fused five-membered rings that have similar puckered ring conformation. Octameric water clusters with cube cagelike or cyclic puckered eight-membered ring conformations have been previously reported. Our observation of cage-shaped geometry of an octameric water cluster in a three-dimensional water network may be due to its different interactions with surrounding water molecules and the coordination-bonding 2D framework. In the cage-shaped octamer, the O···O distance ranges from 2.724 to 2.982 Å, resulting in an average O···O distance of 2.809 Å, which is comparable to those in the ice II phase (2.77−2.84) Å, whereas the average O−O−O angle is 99.26°. Two octamers share a dimer of two O10 atoms to generate a centrosymmetric (H2O)14 cluster. The (H2O)14 clusters arrange orderly, sharing centrosymmetric O11 dimers to form a water tape (Figure b). According to the classifying law of Infantes and Motherwell, this tape can be classified as T5(2)5(3)T5(2)A0. Interestingly, the tape can be viewed as a bilayer water nanotube along the a-axis, with the inner rectangle tube of O10 and O11 water molecules coated by a hexagon tube formed by O7, O9, O12, and O14 water molecules (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: The most startling feature for 1 is the hydrogen-bonding three-dimensional water network. Herein, we describe it stepwisely. A cage-shaped octameric water cluster was formed by a dimmer of two O10 water molecules and a dimer of two centrosymmetric O11 water molecules associated with O7, O9, O12, and O14 water molecules (Figure a). The octamer has four fused five-membered rings that have similar puckered ring conformation. Octameric water clusters with cube cagelike or cyclic puckered eight-membered ring conformations have been previously reported. Our observation of cage-shaped geometry of an octameric water cluster in a three-dimensional water network may be due to its different interactions with surrounding water molecules and the coordination-bonding 2D framework. In the cage-shaped octamer, the O⋅⋅⋅O distance ranges from 2.724 to 2.982 Å, resulting in an average O⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.809 Å, which is comparable to those in the ice II phase (2.77-2.84) Å, whereas the average O-O-O angle is 99.26°. Two octamers share a dimer of two O10 atoms to generate a centrosymmetric (H2O)14 cluster. The (H2O)14 clusters arrange orderly, sharing centrosymmetric O11 dimers to form a water tape (Figure b). According to the classifying law of Infantes and Motherwell, this tape can be classified as T5(2)5(3)T5(2)A0. Interestingly, the tape can be viewed as a bilayer water nanotube along the a-axis, with the inner rectangle tube of O10 and O11 water molecules coated by a hexagon tube formed by O7, O9, O12, and O14 water molecules (Figure c).

elements.content: (a) Cage-shaped octamer in1. (b) Water tape of octamers in 1. (c) Sketch of the bilayer water nanotube in 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Cage-shaped octamer in1. (b) Water tape of octamers in 1. (c) Sketch of the bilayer water nanotube in 1.

elements.content: O13 water molecule hydrogen bonds with two O8 water molecules to form a linear trimer that further hydrogen bonds with two O12 water molecules atoms in the above water tape to generate a crisscross pentama (Figure a). The distances of O13···O8 and O13···O12 are 2.505 and 2.465 Å, respectively. O13 atoms lie on inversion centers, leading to disorder of the hydrogen atoms of O13 over two positions. The pentamers fused with water tape sharing O12 water molecules to assemble the bilayer water nanotubes into a water layer in the [001] plane (Figure d). The water layer contains fused large (H2O)36 water crowns that comprise two (H2O)18 subunits having the shape of a centrosymmetric (H2O)14 cluster fused with a pentamer (Figure c). The O5 molecule hydrogen bonds with an O14 molecule and the O6 molecule hydrogen bonds with an O9 molecule to form helical water chains with opposite chirality (Figure c). The distances of O5···O14 and O6···O9 are 2.771 and 2.793 Å, respectively, and the O5 and O6 atoms lie on the C 2 axes. The opposite chirality helical chains arrange alternately along the c-axis also assembling the water nanotubes into a water layer in the [010] plane (Figure e). Therefore, it can be viewed that the water layers with large water crowns fused with the helical water chains to form the three-dimensional water network with through channels along the a-axis (Figure ). Notably, the three-dimensional water network are constructed by both coordinated and lattice water molecules. This observation indicates that the water network is stabilized not only by hydrogen bonding but also by coordination interactions. Consequently, leaving the water molecules from the coordination spheres out of consideration, the presented water network would become a two-dimensional water layer that can be considered as being O13-linked T5(2)5(3) water tapes. Interestingly, the water tape is formed via two types of pentamers both having cyclic puckered five-membered ring conformations (see the Supporting Information, Figure S4). Furthermore, the three-dimensional water network hydrogen bonds with O2 atoms of BPTC ligands and shares the coordinated water molecules (O5, O6, O7, O8) with the coordination-bonding layer in the [001] plane, resulting in the channels being blocked by the CoII ions and BPTC ligands. The hierarchical assembly process of the final framework of 1 is shown in Figure S5 of the Supporting Information and the geometric parameters of the hydrogen-bonding network are summarized in Table S3 of the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: O13 water molecule hydrogen bonds with two O8 water molecules to form a linear trimer that further hydrogen bonds with two O12 water molecules atoms in the above water tape to generate a crisscross pentama (Figure a). The distances of O13⋅⋅⋅O8 and O13⋅⋅⋅O12 are 2.505 and 2.465 Å, respectively. O13 atoms lie on  inversion centers, leading to disorder of the hydrogen atoms of O13 over two positions. The pentamers fused with water tape sharing O12 water molecules to assemble the bilayer water nanotubes into a water layer in the [001] plane (Figure d). The water layer contains fused large (H2O)36 water crowns that comprise two (H2O)18 subunits having the shape of a centrosymmetric (H2O)14 cluster fused with a pentamer (Figure c). The O5 molecule hydrogen bonds with an O14 molecule and the O6 molecule hydrogen bonds with an O9 molecule to form helical water chains with opposite chirality (Figure c). The distances of O5⋅⋅⋅O14 and O6⋅⋅⋅O9 are 2.771 and 2.793 Å, respectively, and the O5 and O6 atoms lie on the C  2  axes. The opposite chirality helical chains arrange alternately along the c-axis also assembling the water nanotubes into a water layer in the [010] plane (Figure e). Therefore, it can be viewed that the water layers with large water crowns fused with the helical water chains to form the three-dimensional water network with through channels along the a-axis (Figure ). Notably, the three-dimensional water network are constructed by both coordinated and lattice water molecules. This observation indicates that the water network is stabilized not only by hydrogen bonding but also by coordination interactions. Consequently, leaving the water molecules from the coordination spheres out of consideration, the presented water network would become a two-dimensional water layer that can be considered as being O13-linked T5(2)5(3) water tapes. Interestingly, the water tape is formed via two types of pentamers both having cyclic puckered five-membered ring conformations (see the Supporting Information, Figure S4). Furthermore, the three-dimensional water network hydrogen bonds with O2 atoms of BPTC ligands and shares the coordinated water molecules (O5, O6, O7, O8) with the coordination-bonding layer in the [001] plane, resulting in the channels being blocked by the CoII ions and BPTC ligands. The hierarchical assembly process of the final framework of 1 is shown in Figure S5 of the Supporting Information and the geometric parameters of the hydrogen-bonding network are summarized in Table S3 of the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Thermal analysis of 1 reveals that weight loss of water takes place within 30−200 °C. The total weight loss in this temperature range is 40.52% (40.84% calcd), corresponding to 6 coordinated water molecules and 11 lattice water molecules (see the Supporting Information, Figure S6). The onset of decomposition of BPTC ligands starts at about 370 °C.
elements.clean_text: Thermal analysis of 1 reveals that weight loss of water takes place within 30-200 °C. The total weight loss in this temperature range is 40.52% (40.84% calcd), corresponding to 6 coordinated water molecules and 11 lattice water molecules (see the Supporting Information, Figure S6). The onset of decomposition of BPTC ligands starts at about 370 °C.

elements.content: In summary, we have characterized a novel three-dimensional water network formed by the hierarchic assembly of bilayer water nanotubes. The present association mode of cage-shaped octamer, crisscross pentamer, and helical water chains has not been predicted theoretically nor reported experimentally. These new structural data definitely provide novel structural aspects of water and advance our knowledge toward understanding the behavior of bulk water. Furthermore, knowledge obtained from this study may also aid in modeling the role of ordered water in biological systems.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have characterized a novel three-dimensional water network formed by the hierarchic assembly of bilayer water nanotubes. The present association mode of cage-shaped octamer, crisscross pentamer, and helical water chains has not been predicted theoretically nor reported experimentally. These new structural data definitely provide novel structural aspects of water and advance our knowledge toward understanding the behavior of bulk water. Furthermore, knowledge obtained from this study may also aid in modeling the role of ordered water in biological systems.

metadata.title:
Formation of an Infinite Three-Dimensional Water Network by the Hierarchic
Assembly of Bilayer Water Nanotubes of Octamers
